references:
Memory consumption can also be optimized. Note that in our base algorithm (Table 1), the server stores the entire history of selected random seeds and computed gradient scalars.
This can lead to significant memory usage over many rounds.
However, we observe that gradient and seed information older than the most lagged client’s last update is no longer needed.
Since the server already tracks the last updated round for each client, we can efficiently manage the history using a queue.
After clients complete their local updates, the server can discard outdated information from the queue, thus minimizing memory usage.

The base ZOO methods can be replaced as well. For clarity, the algorithm in Table 1 is based on vanilla ZO-SGD, but it can be readily extended to other zeroth-order optimization methods like ZO-SignSGD [46], ZO-SVRG [47], ZO-Adam[48] etc. One pitfall is unlike ZO-SGD, the optimizer is no longer stateless. To ensure synchronization between client and server, this state in the optimizer must also be synchronized, which can be achieved via a reset procedure, as discussed below.

Unlike typical FL algorithms, the communication vector length per round in our proposed algorithm is non-deterministic, depending on the lagged history of each client.
However, we can still compute the amortized communication length per round.
For the pull model step (downlink communication), the vector length is 2​m​K​P×𝒉2𝑚𝐾𝑃𝒉2mKP\times{\boldsymbol{h}}, where the factor 222 comes from the seeds and the gradient scalars, and 𝒉𝒉{\boldsymbol{h}} denotes the length of lagged rounds.
It can be shown that 𝔼​𝒉=Mm𝔼𝒉𝑀𝑚\mathbb{E}\hskip 1.42271pt{\boldsymbol{h}}=\frac{M}{m} as when the total number of rounds R is sufficiently large, all M𝑀M clients will need to pull R​K​P𝑅𝐾𝑃RKP information to rebuild their models.
For the local update step (uplink communication), the returned vector length is always fixed at m​K​P𝑚𝐾𝑃mKP corresponding to K𝐾K local updates with P𝑃P gradient scalars per update for each of the m𝑚m clients.
We summarize the communication complexity in the following table 1.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Comparison of FedDisco (last 4 columns) and MeZO and SGD on fine tuning tasks
S4.T2.table:
Task SGD MeZO # Perturb = 1 # Perturb = 5 # Perturb = 10 Comm. Cost
SST-2 86.40% 84.90% 84.69% 85.16% 86.73% 3e5
CB 77.22% 74.80% 73.85% 74.65% 74.90% 1.2e5
references: To further verify the effectiveness of FedDisco on LLMs, we execute fine-tuning tasks on the SST-2 dataset [51, 52], which is for the sentiment classification task, and CB dataset [53], which is for hypothesis inference problem 111The loading and splitting dataset are based on https://huggingface.co/datasets/super_glue.. The model we used is OPT-125M[54]. Due to the model’s size, we set 3 clients with 2 participating in each round to illustrate the core concept. Table 2 compares FedDisco with varying numbers of perturbations against MeZO and standard SGD fine-tuning as baselines. The learning rate is set to 1e-6 for SST-2 (running 10,000 rounds) and 1e-7 for CB (running 4,000 rounds). The table clearly demonstrates that FedDisco matches MeZO’s performance and can even outperform the first-order approach. Notably, the last column listed the total communication cost of FedDisco with 10 perturbations, which is even less than the size of a single model.
